article.title: The Hard X-ray emission of the blazar PKS 2155--304

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the X-ray light curves of the blazar PKS 2155-304 during different epochs. What can be observed about the variability of the source in the X-ray band?
choices: The source shows no variability in the X-ray band.
The source shows only a single flare-like event during the entire observation period.
The source shows clear variability with recurrent flare-like events during each observation epoch.
The source exhibits a gradual and steady increase in X-ray flux throughout the observation period.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the XMM-Newton light curve of PKS 2155-304 during 2009-2014. Which statement best describes the variability observed in different energy bands?
choices: The source shows the strongest variability in the optical V band.
The variability amplitude is highest in the X-ray band compared to optical and UV bands.
The UVW2 band shows comparable variability amplitude to the X-ray band.
The source exhibits negligible variability in all observed energy bands.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents the spectral fitting of six observations of PKS 2155-304 in the 0.6-10 keV energy range. What is the main spectral model applied to these observations, and what do the subpanels represent?
choices: The main spectral model is a single power-law, and subpanels show residuals for different instruments.
The main spectral model is a blackbody, and subpanels show the contribution from different components.
The main spectral model is a combination of power-law, broken power-law, and log parabolic models, with subpanels showing data-to-model ratios for each model.
The main spectral model is a combination of thermal and non-thermal components, and subpanels show the spectral decomposition.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation describes the log parabolic model for the blazar spectrum. What does the parameter β represent in this model?
choices: β represents the curvature parameter of the spectrum, indicating how the photon index changes with energy.
β represents the break energy in the spectrum where the photon index changes.
β represents the normalization constant of the spectrum.
β represents the intrinsic absorption within the blazar jet.
